div.p: 1. IV:30. Wednesday.

The weather continued showery all the morning, and confined me to the house— It cleared off in the afternoon, cold— John and Charles went to Boston, and returned in the Evening— I gave Charles a Power to receive dividends on U.S. Stocks standing in my name, sealed and attested by two witnesses, but not being acknowledged before a Justice of Peace or Notary, it was not received. By his power of transfer however executed yesterday; he did transfer all the six per Cent Stocks which remained standing in my name; and purchased 43. Shares of the New-England Marine Insurance Company, at 3. per Cent advance; the Certificate of which he brought out with him— John made also a purchase of some furniture. I was employed much of the morning with the inspection of my Chests and Trunks of Books and papers: and began taking a list of my father’s manuscript Letter and Account Books. I find the paper in some of the Books damp, and beginning to grow mouldy; and some appear to be missing. After the sky cleared away I went with the Spade for half an hour into my Nursery; and then rode in the Carriage to visit General Dearborn at Roxbury; but he was he was not at home; and Mrs Dearborn was ill, and could not see me. Returning I called for half an hour at Mr Bailey’s at Dorchester— He purchased at the Sale of Mr Jefferson’s books, his copy of my father’s Defence of the American Constitutions; and shewed me the Volumes— There are no manuscript annotations, but there are penciled indexes at particular passages, in the first and third Volumes and at the close of each of those Volumes written references to those pages, with asterisks over some of the references— The passages are all those which speak of the natural aristocracy in human Society; of its tendency to be continued in families, and of the expediency, of constituting them one branch of the Legislature. There is nothing that indicates any particular attention given by Mr Jefferson to any other part of the Book— When I got home I found at the house a man who said his name was Layton, and who from his conversation, appeared to be insane. His object was merely to see me—
2. IV:30. Thursday.

Charles went into Boston this morning, and returned in the Evening. He brought out some of the papers of my father which had been in the possession of my Son George— The furniture purchased yesterday by John was also brought out— Chairs Tables, and a Straw Carpet. A Bust was also brought of those sent by Mr Greenough, but it proved to be of me— I had not bespoken it, nor did I expect it. Coll. Quincy told me there were two; but that of my father is yet to come. Mr Benjamin son of Deacon Jonathan Bass was here this morning, wishing to borrow Money upon a mortgage of a house he has lately built and to dispose of a share in the Quincy Canal—which I took into consideration, and said I would see him again Saturday Morning. I made my second attempt with the Spade in my Nursery, before dinner, for about half an hour which thoroughly fatigued me— I expect by practice to be able to work longer; and it will serve me for exercise. I am arrested in the assortment of my fathers books by missing two or three of them which
are yet to be found— I commenced some other preparations for the collection of materials to write a biographical Memoir of my father. But I dally too long. Judge Thacher with Dr Parkman, visited me from Boston, and also Mr Degrand— I rode with my Son John down to the Mount Wollaston Farm, and saw the tenant Spear, who as usual is complaining. We called at Josiah Brigham’s and the Briesler’s, and rode round by the House built by Benjamin Bass and which he wishes to mortgage— Mr George W. Beale, and Price Greenleaf were here in the Evening— Mr Greenleaf took some of the Cedar Apples which I have received from E. Wyer. Degrand spent the Evening here till ten O’Clock. He says Joseph E. Sprague wrote to Mr Clay to enquire whether it would be advisable that the Legislature of Massachusetts should nominate him for the next Presidency— This was before their recent Session— Mr Clay’s answer was that the elections to the Kentucky Legislature next August would turn entirely upon the question of supporting him— That if his party should prevail the Legislature would nominate him; after which others might do as they should think proper. I told Mr Degrand that I thought this good advice— He said that the manufacturers were urgent for the immediate nomination of Mr Clay; but he agreed that it would be best to wait till the Winter Session of the Legislature; and then to act as the circumstances of the time may render proper.
3. IV.30— Friday—

Charles went into Boston, this morning and returned this Evening. Mr Noah Curtis father of Adam and Samuel Curtis, called upon me about the half acre of Land which Samuel wished to purchase of me, and upon which he proposes to build a house— The land was appraised at the rate of 600 dollars an Acre— I told Samuel last week that I should ask 400 dollars for a half Acre—eight rods in front and ten rods deep; and the father now said he wished it to be considered as settled, that he would take it— I told him that I proposed to have all my land upon and round Penn’s Hill surveyed and planned; and that this half-Acre might be measured off at the same time— He said the land itself had belonged to his Great grandfather, and that there had never been a time for these 160 years, without a Samuel Curtis in this Town. I worked with the Spade an hour and a half in the Nursery before dinner— I propose to substitute this exercise instead of riding on horseback; neither of my horses being suitable for the saddle. On turning my attention to the papers relating to the Execution of my father’s will I found there was much to be done by me, and I began the preparation of the papers to be executed. My bond of 4. Octr. 1826. requires a systematic continuation of performance by me for a series of years to come, which had almost escaped my recollection, but which I cannot forget with impunity— Mrs Humphreys from Boston paid me a visit this afternoon— I rode to Dorchester, and returned the visits of the Revd. Mr Codman, and of Coll. Quincy. I called also upon Mr Withington the Surveyor, to enquire if he could make the surveys of my Lands, which I propose, but he is so infirm in health that he cannot undertake it— He recommended to me a nephew of his by the name of Mosely. Mr Curtis had recommended a Mr Humphreys of Weymouth, and my brother a Mr Ellis of Dedham. I spoke to Coll. Quincy of the Busts, and he said that the
bust of myself had been sent to me by mistake, and belonged to Mr Greenough’s father; who had retained that of my father in its stead. I desired Mr Quincy to let his father know that I should be glad to see him, when he should come out here. Mrs. Quincy said they had kept fires the last three days— An East wind with cold cloudy weather and morning fogs has prevailed this is the fourth day; after three of successive Showers.
4. IV:30. Saturday— Independence day— John 26

Captain John Williams, master of the vessel in which Edward Wyer came last from Smyrna called upon me, and delivered to me a pair of Turkish Slippers, which Wyer gave him in charge for me— This was yesterday— Captain Williams said he had come out to see the railway— He also said he was much disposed to abandon the Sea-faring life— This morning Benjamin Bass brought the title deed of the land upon which he has built his house, and a printed mortgage partly filled up; but which I desired him to have executed, and bring to me next Tuesday— He mentioned that his brothers Lewis and Isaac Bass had purchased all Captain John Bass’s Land adjoining upon mine, on the hill where I propose to build. That part adjoining me he said Isaac had taken— I requested him to say to his brother Isaac that I wished to speak with him about it— Mr Bass seemed disposed to talk politics also this being Independence day— I had received from the Mayor of Boston a Card of invitation in behalf of the City Government to meet them in Faneuil Hall this morning at 11. O’Clock, to reciprocate congratulations on the day, and to attend the City celebration of the Anniversary— I answered this Card, declining the invitation, and my Son John took my answer to Boston, and returned this Evening. Charles passed the day with me— I went with him to my brother’s where his daughter Elizabeth signed a receipt of the portion payable to her, by my father’s Will, upon her coming of age; for which she took my Note— The interest due upon my Notes on the first instt. was also paid both to her Sister Abigail and to her; and I gave them both my advice with regard to the Settlement upon each of them, of their respective portions, from which I wish to be discharged, and that it may be so secured to them that they shall receive the interest, the principle remaining intangible by themselves, or by their husbands if they should marry— I recommended to them to have it placed in trust, in the Hospital Life insurance Company in Boston. They are to take it into Consideration— Returning home across the Hills, I found at the House, Mr Degrand who had walked out from Boston, and who dined with us— He also walked back to the City— This is the first quiet fourth of July that I have enjoyed for the last twelve years— But it suspended partly my occupations of Industry— Weather still cold, with East winds.
5. IV:30. Sunday.

Easterly Storm— Rain all the morning Beclouded all the rest of the day. Heard Mr Whitney this Morning from 2. Corinthians 7.2. “We have corrupted no man, we have defrauded no man.” the latter part of the verse— The discourse was practical. The duty of all Christians to regulate their conduct so as to be enabled to affirm the same of themselves was enforced in plain language, and with Mr Whitney’s usual earnestness of manner. The examples of corrupting others against which he directed his admonitions were adapted to his auditory and suited to making good impressions— His afternoon Sermon was from 2. Peter 3.16. part of the verse— “In which are some things hard to be understood.” This remark of Peter which is made of the Epistles of Paul, Mr Whitney considered as applicable to the Scriptures generally and especially to the New Testament. His particular object was to explain certain passages in the gospel of Matthew, and he had preached a previous Sermon of which this was the continuation— He attributed the difficulties of understanding the Scriptures to the figurative language with which they abound, and said there was more of such language in the Bible, than in any other Book— The passages which he commented upon were however only two or three in St. Matthew and he did not go very deep for his explanations; but he observed that which must and ought to satisfy every searcher into the Scriptures, that the difficult passages are not those which are necessary to regulate the conduct of human life— That these are all plain and easy. Such is my own belief, although a man of mind disputatious with itself may find perplexities in every verse— The weather confined me to the house the remnant of the day, but John went into Boston, to put a Letter into the Post-Office; and brought me one out from Mr Monroe. I spent the Evening in Conversation with Charles.
6— IV:20. Monday.

Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned this Evening. Mr William Smith, brother of Mrs Charles Miller paid me a visit— He has been much out of health with a pulmonary complaint but is recovering. A change of weather has at length taken place, and this day was warm. Between Noon and two O’Clock, I worked with my Spade in the Nursery, but found the heat oppressive— I answered Mr Monroe’s Letter, and after dinner read a few of those of Madame du Deffand— Towards Evening I walked to my brother’s and met, on the way Mr Daniel Greenleaf and Mr Peele of Salem, who had just returned from Cohasset where they had been to make a quarterly visit to a young man named Alfred Appleton, under their joint-guardianship— I returned the visit of Mr Edward Miller, and then called at my brother’s. His wife is confined to her chamber by indisposition, and Dr Woodward came in while I was there. Abby and Elizabeth were
gone out. They had called upon me this morning and informed me of their wishes, that they should continue to hold the notes upon interest, for 3000 dollars each which I have given them on their respectively coming of age, in payment of my fathers bequests to them; because they could not place it in trust at the hospital life Insurance company, without some diminution of the interest. I consented that they should continue to hold my Notes for the present— My brother informed me that our Cousin Boylston Adams died last Saturday Night— He has been for several years under the guardianship of his Sister’s Son Peter Turner. While I was out this Evening Dr Welsh, and Dr Shattuck came to visit me, but did not stay. Thomas Welsh junr. was this day arrested and imprisoned for debt in Boston.
7. IV. Tuesday— Sun rose 4:31.

Mr Bass and George Veazie called early this morning: and the mortgage and note were executed; and a former note of Bass to Veazie was taken up, and he signed a discharge of the mortgage, given to secure payment of it— Bass urged me again to take his Canal share; and offered to take in part payment his father’s Note to the Executors of my father. I told him I would make enquiries of the value of the shares, and proposed that he should call upon me again— He said he must then come earlier in the morning; for that he should now lose almost half a day’s work by coming here this morning. I told him he might come by Sunrise. Charles went to Boston, and returned this Evening— I worked about an hour with the Spade; but the heat was more oppressive than the labour— Perseverance in this Exercise would I have no doubt be beneficial to my health, but shall I have the perseverance? At three O’Clock this afternoon I attended the funeral of my Cousin Boylston Adams, who has closed his career at the age of fifty-eight— His prospects were always humble but at one time were according to his condition in life very fair. Of late years they have been deeply clouded with disease and infirmity— He has left a widow and five daughters; ill provided for. Mr Whitney performed the funeral service at the house; and I rode with my brother to the burying ground, and walked home. My reflections upon the decease of Boylston Adams are naturally melancholy— Is it not possible that they should be made useful? Of all lessons that which teaches cheerfulness under all the dispensations of Providence may contribute most to human happiness— I wasted no inconsiderable portion of this day upon trifles— Mr and Mrs Cruft paid us a visit from Boston. Lemuel Brackett was here towards Evening, and he spoke of certain lots of land belonging to him and bordering upon mine— He had mentioned these to me last year, and proposed to sell me his lots; I had deferred answering him then, and now found it necessary to decline the purchase; but agreed to let him know when my lots would be surveyed— My brother brought me this morning the lease of the Mount Wollaston farm to Alpheus and Lemuel Spear; and the Act of Incorporation of the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund— I asked him for his Account with me, which he promised.
8— IV:30. Wednesday— Dedham Probate Court.

Mr Bass came this morning and urged me again to take his Share in the Quincy Canal giving him for it a check for 70 dollars, and his father’s Note to the Executors of my father for forty dollars given 3. October 1826. with interest two years and nine Months, being 5:60. which was set off by a receipt from Jonathan Bass for a pair of Boots furnished me in September 1827. charged 5. dollars and upon which I allowed interest also from that time. Morning visit from Mr Jones and Mr Bicker.— We dined at one and immediately after dinner I went to Dedham to attend the probate Court— I first took my Deeds to the Register’s Office— I found there a young man named Cobb, who told me that Mr Enos Foord the Register was gone upon a short excursion for his health, and left him in charge of the Office. He took and minuted my Deeds; but observed that the discharge of George Veazie’s mortgage, though signed by him and witnessed on the back of the mortgage was not conformable to the Statute of the Commonwealth; because not sealed or acknowledged before a Justice of the Peace— On looking to the act I found that the Release must be sealed and acknowledged, or the mortgagee must repair to the Register’s Office, and there sign an acknowledgment of the discharge of the Mortgage, on the margin of the record— I took back the mortgage, to have Veazie’s discharge duly executed upon it— Leaving the Deed from Ebenezer and Josiah Adams to me, and Bass’s mortgage to me to be recorded— I found at the Probate Office, Mr Nathaniel Curtis and Mr John Lane Boylston, and I signed with Mr Curtis, the first Account of the Administration, made out by him, to which we were sworn; I stating to the Judge Robbins that my oath was given in confidence of the accuracy of Mr Curtis’s proceedings— The judge proposed and directed an allowance of 5 per Cent to the Executors on the monies disbursed— I said I should receive no part of it hitherto: having taken until this time no active part in the Administration. Mr John L. Boylston has a claim upon the Estate for eighteen years of services to his father at 500 dollars a year— The Executors referred this claim to the judge, who declined deciding upon it by his authority, but proposed a reference of it, to judge Payne of Worcester. Mr Goodwin of Princeton, and Mr Russell of that neighbourhood, to which all parties present assented, and the judge said a Commission should be made out accordingly— I spoke of my appointment as guardian of the two Grandsons of Mr Boylston, Ward Nicholas and Thomas, and referred to the two passages in the will concerning it— But there being some question as to the extent of the guardianship intended by the testator, the judge deferred issuing the Letters of Guardianship till his next probate Court, which will be held at Quincy on the first Tuesday of next Month; when I told him I expected there would be an account of the Executors of my father to be settled— After leaving the Court I went with Mr Curtis and Mr John L. Boylston to Bride’s tavern; and looked over Mr. Petty Vaughan’s Account with the
Executors, and some questions occurring respecting the monies to be recovered from the Estate of T Boylston, Mr Curtis wished me to see and converse with Mr. John Lowell, who was employed by Mr Ward N. Boylston, upon the settlement of the Estate, and I agreed to call upon Mr Curtis to-morrow afternoon, and go with him to see Mr Lowell— I got home at Quincy between 8 and 9 in the Evening.
9. IV. Thursday— Jamaica Plains— J. Lowell’s—

Mr Cary came out from Boston, and I went with him to the Meeting House and we viewed the place on the Wall where I propose to fix the monumental tablet with the Inscription in Memory of my father and mother. He had a book with him of engraved models of such monuments some of which may be consulted when we fix upon the final plan— I am to call upon him in Boston and we are to examine together the monument of Mrs Shirley in the Stone chapel. I called on Mr Brigham, Treasurer of the Canal Corporation, and gave him the certificate of the Share transferred to me by Benjamin Bass, to have one made out in my name. I then went to Mr Bass, and gave him the mortgage to Veazie, with a release on the back of it for Veazie to execute, and walked across the hills home— Dr and Miss Hill paid a morning visit. We dined at one, and immediately after dinner I went to Jamaica Plains; called at Dr Gray’s, where at the door I saw George Whitney, but Dr Gray was not at home— I took up Mr Curtis at his house, and went with him to Mr John Lowell’s, and from him received several papers relating to Mr. Ward N. Boylston’s Estate and a narrative of the principal transactions of his connection with the Affairs and Estate of Thomas Boylston— It is the most complicated individual history that ever came to my knowledge, and Mr Ward N. Boylston’s proceedings in it were managed with more success resulting from his industry and perseverance than I have ever observed in any other case. There are however some grave questions still pending concerning his rights and particularly concerning the rights and duties of his Executors with regard to the Estate of T. Boylston— From Mr Lowell’s statements I now understand how the legal advisors of Petty Vaughan, have perswaded him to call upon me for a release of my rights as representing one of his devisees— After about two hours of conversation with Mr Lowell I returned with Mr Curtis to his house; there called at Mr B— Busseys, but he was not at home; and I got back to Quincy just at Sunset. Mr Curtis offered to go with me to visit my farm at Weston, and I accepted his offer. Mr G. W. Beale was here in the Evening, and spoke of the buildings he is erecting at Squantum; which he says have been in meditation these thirty-five years. He thinks the Quincy Canal Shares not worth more than 60 dollars each— The appraisers of George’s effects have this day appraised his share at that sum; and I have given Bass 110 dollars for his— I shall not pass for a close bargainer. Foster were here from Boston, and Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf paid us an Evening visit. Mr Isaac Smith, Mr Mrs and Miss Hall, Mrs S. A. Otis and her daughter called here while I was gone out— I desired Mr Curtis to converse with Mrs Boylston, and to look in to Mr Boylston’s Will to ascertain who is to bear the expense of subsistence and education of his two Grandsons.
10. IV.15. Friday— John went for Washington.

My Son John went to Boston this morning with his brother, and is to proceed to-morrow upon his return to Washington— I wrote to my wife; worked half an hour with the spade between Noon and two O’Clock; bathed at 6. in the afternoon at Mr D. Greenleaf’s wharf, and spent the Evening with a social party at his house. It was the first warm day since we arrived here— The water was of good temperature. Judge Whitman and his son, with Mr Daniel Greenleaf paid me an afternoon visit— The judge remembered his visit to me at Washington in 1814 with Mrs Whitman, and told me that he was at Barnum’s at Baltimore with her, on the Night that I last passed there, when coming on to this place; but did not know I was there till after I had retired to bed. I agreed this Evening with Mr T. Greenleaf to go with him to the Hill, to-morrow morning.— I read this afternoon a few of the Letters of Madame du Deffand—among the rest that which relates the freak of Louis 15. in writing at ten O’Clock at Night to the Bishop of Orleans, for cotignac for the king’s daughters— The Letters are amusing; but the excessive fondness of the old Lady for Horace is inexplicable. It is too steady to place to the account of caprice; too warm from the heart, for imputing it to insincerity, too absurd for bringing within any line of reason. Such Letters should be read as they are received, only one at a time.
11. IV. Saturday.— My birth-day. 62.

I enter this day upon my grand climacteric, with a consciousness that the actions of my life, have not in gratitude to God, or in services to my fellow creatures been such as they ought to have been. I have no right to hope or expect so well of the future than I can think of the past. My life for the public is closed and it only remains for me to use my endeavours to make the remainder of it useful to my family and my neighbours if possible. To this I am directing my purposes, for which I find a great deficiency of energy. I pray that it may be supplied me from abroad— A person by the name of Chamberlin came this Morning to offer me another Share of the Quincy Canal, for which he asked 200 dollars— I offered him 130 dollars for the Share and Note; the rate at which the Share I gave George was appraised in Boston, and at which Mr Beale estimates them. He declined taking this but Charles said he would come back— A man by the name of Williams who had much the appearance of a vagabond and rogue, sent me a Letter marked private, and begging a few minutes of private conversation— He pretended to be an Englishman, but his Speech was Irish— He told me a long Story of a Shipwreck, and of a Gentleman in New-York, who had five thousand pounds Sterling of his, in deposit and whose name he had forgotten, and he had now but a few Cents, and wanted Assistance; any that I was disposed to give him; which was nothing. Charles went to Boston
and goes this Evening to Medford; Mr Everett having returned home, and Abby Brooks who has been this fortnight with Mrs Everett has gone back to her fathers. Mr Thomas Greenleaf came, and I walked with him upon the Hill; I shewed him the place where I propose to build a House, if I find it practicable— I conversed with him upon the proposal for opening of the Square on which the School House is to be built; and of a plan to be prepared by the Supervisors of the Temple and School Fund— During the vacation at Cambridge, Mr Quincy will pass some time here, and we agreed that there should then be a Meeting of the Supervisors— It will be necessary for me to address to them in writing, all that I have to propose— Morning visits from Mr Melville, late Naval Officer at Boston, and his Son, and General Dearborn; with whom I had some conversation, about the treatment of the Crevecoeur breed of fowls, which I take to be the same as Buffon calls the Poule de Caux. Visits also from Mr Silsbee, of Salem, and Mr Rice of Boston, and in the afternoon from Mr Artiguenave, his wife, recently married and his two Sons. In the Evening I finished reading Buffon’s Natural History of the Cock, in which there are many good observations but which appears to me superficial— Closed the Evening writing in my chamber.
12. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Thomas Gannett of Cambridge-port, in the morning from Matthew 7.21. “Not every one that saith unto me Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my father which is in Heaven” and in the afternoon from 2. Corinthians 10.1 part of the verse “I beseech you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ.” Both the discourses were upon the peculiar Spirit of Christianity; humility, benevolence and Charity— They were well written and well read; perhaps rather too slow; but with good accent and emphasis and without cant— The auditory listened with great attention. Alpheus Spear had a child baptised by the name of Abigail Knapp. The Deportment and appearance of this Congregation strikes me as very highly improved within a few years— The House writes elegance with simplicity, and has an evident moral influence upon the Society— There is a Choir of Singers male and female consisting of young persons in humble but respectable life, whose performance is creditable and improving; and amounting to about thirty in number. There is no Organ but a Violoncello, and Violin. Dr Belknap’s selection of Psalms and Hymns is excellent, and the younger preachers shew their taste and judgment, in giving out for the singers those which are best adapted to the purport of their Sermons— The tendency of all this is to soften, to civilize, and to promote morals and happiness— Will the blessing of God continue upon these efforts? and may they be pursued with pure intention, and devout sincerity? After the second service Edward Cranch called upon me; and afterwards a person by the name of Chapin from Providence— I drafted an Account for my fathers Executors and a deed to be executed by them— Began a Letter to the Supervisors.
13. IV. Monday.

Saturday afternoon I rode alone with one of my horses in the Chaise to Braintree, and by a road where I had never passed before crossed into the old road from Weymouth over Penn’s Hill. This morning immediately after breakfast I spaded one hour in my Nursery, and believe this may answer for the exercise of a day. I finished my Letter to the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund. Russell Freeman late Collector at New-Bedford, paid me a morning visit: being on his return from Boston with his wife: he told me of an affray, he lately had with his Successor Lemuel Williams, for which he Freeman has been bound over to the Supreme Court of the State— He said he was well disposed to do his best to change the present order of things— In the afternoon I had a visit from Mr Rufus G. Amory, who now resides at Stirling, but was now going with his Sister Mrs. M’lean to visit at Mr Marston’s. Mr Ebenezer Francis, Treasurer of Harvard University was here with the papers of Mr W. N. Boylston’s foundations of Medical prize Dissertations. There was a bond and mortgage of the first, both in my hand writing, and acknowledged before me as a Justice of the Peace in April 1803. which had escaped entirely my recollection— There was a Bond also upon the Institution of the Elocution prizes; purporting to have annexed to it a Regulation for the manner of performing the prize declamations, but it was not so annexed, nor has any such paper been found among those of the late President Kirkland. He filed no papers as the late Treasurer judge Davis kept no books of Accounts— Mr Curtis had put into my hands a Copy of this missing Document which was among Mr Boylston’s papers— I gave it to Mr Francis, advising that a copy of it should be made; annexed to the original bond, and certified by the Executors— The institution cannot be made effective without it— The Legacies of Mr Boylston to Harvard University, are of three separate sums of 1000 dollars each, besides three Portraits; and they seem to be additional to the sums which he had secured to the University by the two Bonds, and the Mortgage during his life time— But into this I must further examine, and consult with my Co-executors.— There is among the rest a question whether the Legacies shall be paid during the life of Mrs Boylston— I rode this afternoon, over to Mr C. Tufts’s at Weymouth. Stop’d at Harvey Fields—but he was not at home—at Noah Curtis’s and spoke to him of the Parish Treasurer’s Notes to the Executors of my father, and to me— He said he expected to be able to pay the interest on both, and if I wished it the principal of the Note to the Executors by the first of October; when the second payment on the Meeting House Pews will become due. I asked Mr Tufts if he had the Will of Norton Quincy, of which his father was the Executor— Mrs Tufts said he had not; that neither that Will, nor that of old Coll. Josiah Quincy, of which Dr Tufts was also the Executor, had been found after Dr Tufts’s decease; and she mentioned a Bank Book of my fathers which had been, long missing but had finally been found. On returning home I found Charles who had come out from Boston; and brought with him Letters from my wife; from P. R. Fendall, and a singular one from David Barnum of Baltimore—also one for my Son John from his wife—
14. IV. Tuesday.

Charles went in to Boston this Morning, and returned this Evening. I bathed and swam at Mr D— Greenleaf’s wharf between 9 and 10 at the high-tide— I feel the want of steady application to particular objects at stated hours of the day— The Diary absorbs the morning till breakfast, and often an hour afterwards— I propose to devote the next leisure time to answering Letters then to the Execution of Mr W. N. Boylston Will—and my fathers; and then to reading. This with a necessary portion of exercise absorbs the day; but there is yet great waste of time— I wrote this day Letters to my wife and to P. R. Fendall— There are so many questions arising from Mr Boylston’s Will, that I have concluded to make a copy of it myself in a book leaving the left hand pages blank, for remarks and began with it this day. I read two or three Letters of Madame du Deffand, and the Dedication to Sir Robert Walpole of Bolingbroke’s Dissertation upon Parties— The History of Parties in Great Britain from the reign of James the first till the close of the War of the American Revolution deserves to be profoundly studied by American Statesmen— The last years of the reign of Queen Anne, and the Administration of Walpole are the portions of it, to which there appears to be the strongest resemblance in our own history— This afternoon, towards Evening, I walked to my brother’s, but he was gone with his wife, to take tea at Mrs Miller’s; while I was out Mr Jonathan Davis and his Son were here. I did not see them.
15. IV. Wednesday.

The Summer begins to shew itself—my Fahrenheit was at 85. and I indulged myself in trifling indolence pleading to my self the heat of the weather— The high tide was marked in the Almanack at 10.47. I went to the wharf at that time; but the tide had turned about half an hour— The high tide at New and Full Moon at Boston is at Noon. I swam to the lower wharf, and was twenty minutes in the water— I wrote to my Son John a Short Letter, and recommenced a copy of Mr W. N. Boylston’s Will. I also resumed the observations upon parties, but found the work so tedious that I wrote less than half a page— Charles went in to Boston, but did not come out this evening. In the afternoon Judge Davis, and his nephew called upon me, returning from Plymouth, where they had been attending the funeral of the judge’s brother, Samuel, who died suddenly in the Night of last Friday. I walked towards evening, and visited Mrs Charles Miller, and her brother who lives with her Mr W. Smith— Returning, I called at my brother’s— He was gone to Medford with his daughter Abigail, but they returned while I was there— Mr Marston and William Greenleaf came in, and Mr Marston talked of his father, and General Winslow, and the taking of Louisbourg in 1745. When I came home I found a packet from Richardson and Lord, printers and Booksellers at Boston enclosing a manuscript translation of the Observations upon the Government and Laws of the United States addressed to my father by the Abbe de Mably; sent to them from New-York by a Mr Tessier; offering it to them for 150 dollars, for publication; but he erroneously supposes that no English translation
of the work had ever been published before. Richardson and Lord send it to me for my opinion upon it, and whether it would be a good printer’s speculation to prinit it. The translator informs them that he has two other works of the Abbe de Mably, which he offers them upon the same terms— One on the principles of Moral Philosophy; and one upon the rights and duties of a Citizen— There was a sprinkling of rain this afternoon of which I received my share while walking; and the edge of a remote thunder gust.
16. IV. Thursday.

Pursued my occupations, again with some interruption of visitors, and also by the heat of the weather. Bathed at the wharf at Noon, and took a slight hurt upon the knee coming out— Going to the Office in the farm-house to look for the old English Translation of the Abbe de Mably’s Observations on the Government and Laws of the United States, I found the Library in great disorder, and the unbound Books and papers perishing with moths— I determined to set the Library in Order, and selected some of the Books to have them bound— The operation of putting the Library in order will consume much time; and I hope not to leave it unfinished— Towards Evening I took a ride in the Chaise alone, to Milton, and to Squantum where I saw the building which Mr George W. Beale is erecting— When I came home I found Charles here. He brought with him a Volume of 18 Sermons by Dr Freeman, presented, to me by the author— I answered the Letter of Richardson and Lord.
17. IV. Friday.

Mr Brooks and his daughter paid me an unexpected visit this Morning, and went afterwards to my brother’s. He invited me to Medford to-morrow. At Noon I bathed at the wharf, and swam to the lower wharf. Greenough’s Bust of my father was brought out from Boston by Mr Baxter, with the Pipe of Madeira Wine from New-York— I proceeded in the examination of the old papers at the Office but only consumed time without making any progress towards the arrangement of them. Towards Evening I walked to Mr T. Greenleaf’s, and looked over his Gardens where he has many exotic trees in cultivation. I gave him also the Letter which I had written to the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund, and found by conversation with him, that the subjects of which it speaks have been already under consideration of the Town and Parish— It is doubtful whether the School can be erected for several if not many years to come— On my return home, Charles was here, and gave me a Letter from my wife— She had received notice to quit Meridian Hill, on the first of August, the Sale of the place having been completed. She is in trouble where to remove, and writes that John’s house will not be finished in time— I executed this morning three Powers of Attorney to my Son Charles—one authorising him to Lease my Real Estate in Boston and at Quincy, and two to attend at Meetings of Stockholders, and receive dividends on my shares in the West-Boston and Neponset Bridges. I answered Judge Van der Kemp’s Letter, and read three or four of Madame du Deffand’s Letters— One particularly in which she gives him her doubts of a future state of existence, and asks his opinion— An extract from his answer is given; rather evasive; professing a firm belief in the existence of a good and wide God; but nothing more.
18. IV:15. Saturday— Boston— Medford— Quincy.

Mr Tufts and his daughter paid us a morning visit— Mr Tufts left with me the Will of Norton Quincy, and the Inventory of his Estate— I went in to Boston— Stop’d at the work-shop of Cary and Dickinson’s the Stone-Cutters— Cary was not there, but Dickinson engaged to find him, and that he should meet me at the Stone Chapel at half past twelve— I called at Mr James H. Foster’s, where I saw Mrs Foster—her daughters Elizabeth and Louisa; and her Son William who is to be graduated this year at Cambridge— I left John Porter with my horses at Gragg’s stable— Left Cards at Judge Davis’s, J. B. Davis’s, Lieutt. Governor Winthrop’s and Judge P. O. Thacher’s—visited Mrs S. A. Otis, and at Dr. Welsh’s, where I saw the Doctor and Harriet— On visiting that House, my maker only knows the feelings with which I was affected— Half a century of associations, pleasing and painful weighed upon my heart as I approached the house; and it is now the abode of deep distress— In a few days to be sold for the debts of the two Sons who have failed; and leaving the family without a home— I invited the Doctor and Harriet to come next Saturday, and pass the Sunday with me at Quincy, which they conditionally accepted— I then went and met Mr Cary at the Stone Chapel; and there examined the Monuments to John Vassall, to Charles Ward Apthorp, and to the wife and daughter of Governor Shirley. The last is that which best pleases me. I then went to my Son Charles’s Office— He went to Gragg’s stable, and soon returned with the carriage; we went and dined at Mr P. C. Brooks’s at Medford— Edward Brooks and his wife: Sidney Brooks and his wife—Mr Everett and Mrs Frothingham; Mr Stetson the Minister of the Parish, and Miss Phillips were the company— The state of Mrs Brooks’s health shed a gloom over the party which would otherwise have been pleasant. They urged me to stay and pass the Sunday with them, but I had promised to return to Quincy. After dinner I walked with Mr Brooks round his garden which is in admirable order— I left Charles there, and about six O’Clock left them, and returned through Boston home, which I reached before nine. I received a note from Mr Josiah Quincy junr. informing me that his father was here, with an invitation to tea this afternoon.
19. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr White of Dedham, in the morning from Deuteronomy 6.6. “And these words which I command thee this day, shall be in thine heart: 7. And thou shalt teach them diligently unto thy children, and shalt talk of them when thou sittest in thine house, and when thou walkest by the way, and when thou liest down, and when thou risest up.” The text of the afternoon I did not retain which I ascribe partly to the decay of my own memory and partly to the coldness of the preacher’s manner— His discourses are sensibly written, and he reads them with propriety, but the matter and the manner are frigid— I read however a Sermon of Mr James Freeman; the first of the Volume which he has recently published; and of which he has sent me a copy— His text is 2. Cor. 5.7. “We walk by faith, and not by sight.” Cool and argumentative— A plausible answer to deeply perplexing questions— Why the Creator has not seen fit more clearly to disclose to man the certainty of his own existence, and of Man’s immortality. Human Reason, is sufficient to perceive the difficulty, but not
to discover its solution— I occupied myself as well as I could, through the day; for when I am not intent upon something of future interest, the pangs of the past, and the terrors of what may be to come, wring my Soul almost to desperation— I walked this Evening to Coll. Quincy’s, to see his Mother— She was there with her daughters Susan and Anna, Mr. and Mrs Greene; and Mrs Miller; the Coll.’s wife’s Mother— Coll. Quincy and Mr Greene walked home with me— Abigail Adams had been here— The family are in great concern at the delay of the Lieutenant T. B. Adams, who has been expected here these ten days— I fear they have too much cause for their alarm.
20. IV:30. Monday.

This Mr Bass is another Son of Jonathan’s and brother of Benjamin’s. He came upon a similar purpose to that of his brother; that is to mortgage his lands worth as he says 2800 dollars for a loan of 1500 dollars for five years. But I had no money to lend. He offered me also for sale a House and 3/4 of an Acre of Land which he owns bordering on my land in Penn’s valley— He asks 2000 dollars for it, and says it is now rented to three families from whom he receives a rent of 112 dollars a year they paying all the taxes— My tasked employments occupied me till past Noon— At one I bathed, and swam to the lower wharf—absent exactly one hour. Read after dinner three or four Letters from Madame du Deffand; and the most amusing thing I found in them was that Mr Walpole had informed her that the Walls of one of his Apartments at Strawberry Hill were Pea-green, upon which she had never before heard of Verd de pois. Charles came out from Boston early this afternoon; and had brought out with him Lieutt. T. B. Adams junr. who has at length arrived— I had been under much anxiety for him, the last two days; from being so long without hearing from him— Deep and Sudden misfortune unsettles the mind, and opens the heart to unreasonable foreboding terrors. As indications of divine chastisement, they astonish, and confound, and leave us doubtful when they will cease— The observation that misfortunes seemingly having no connection together do come nearly together has often been made, and is justified by so much experience that I cannot separate the apprehension of it from my present condition— It poisons every hour of my life, and leaves nothing for me to trust, but the mercy of my maker— I rode with Charles down to the Mount Wollaston farm where I saw Alpheus Spear— Evening in Conversation with Charles at home.
21. IV:15. Tuesday.

Abigail S. Adams went into Boston this Morning with Charles and the Lieutenant passed two hours with me— Hence part of my task was thrown upon the afternoon— My task is as much as I expect to be able to perform, one day with another, but it has not yet assumed its proper character. I bathed and swam from wharf to wharf before dinner and took a nap of two hours immediately after dinner— Finished reading the first Volume of Madame du Deffand’s Letters— Heat of the weather oppressive till evening. I found several of the Larvae of the Peach-tree worm just at the surface of the ground, round the root of a young tree in the garden, which was budded the Summer before last— They are now about coming out in the form of a Fly— Joseph Burrell came to borrow money upon a mortgage, but I have none to lend— Charles came out in the Evening.
22. IV. Wednesday.

Mr Solomon Thayer is an old man belonging to Braintree, and says he is a relation of mine. He brought me a sample of Oats for four Quarts of which he made me pay him two dollars. The history that he gave of them was this That four years since he purchased and sowed a quantity of grass seed— That with the grass of that seed there came up a single stalk from one kernel of Oats, which soon attracted his attention by outgrowing the grass. That it grew to a height of near five feet and seeded That from that seed he raised the next year an handful, the third year more than a pint, and this year he has near a bushel of the Oats— They have grown with his grass: he had with him a bundle of the Stalks which were nearly five feet high: he says they weigh 32 pounds to the bushel, and will yield ninety bushels to the Acre— Cattle and the fowls are greedy of the seed, of which he has exhibited a specimen to the Agricultural Society, and was advised by them to keep choicely every kernel of the seed— The original stalk though cut with his grass continues alive and yields seed every year. I gave credit to this marvelous tale, and took four Quarts of his seed at his own price to make an experiment with it. The day was the warmest there has been this Summer, and my thermometer in the house at 86. I did nothing but my task, and towards Evening rode to Dorchester and Roxbury, and returned the visits of Mr T. K. Jones and Mr Bicker, and of General Sumner, who was not at home— On returning I found Charles here; he brought me Letters from my wife and from W. B. Lawrence enclosing one from the Marquis de Marbois.
23. IV:30. Thursday.

My nephew, Lieutt. T. B. Adams jr. came and spent the day with us. Charles went in to Boston this Morning and to Medford this Evening. Coll. Thayer, Superintendent of the Military Academy at West Point paid a morning visit—also Mr. Marston with a Mr Randall from Philadelphia, father of the lawyer, and his Son in Law Mr Erp— In the afternoon Dr Holbrook called, and Mr Hackett a lawyer from Portsmouth New-Hampshire, brought me a Letter of Introduction from the late member of Congress Ichabod Bartlett— Mr Hackett comes from Saratoga Springs, where he has been passing a Month, and is returning home— No small portion of my Time is now occupied with small household affairs and the details of housekeeping— I sent for Mr Taylor and ordered a load of Oak wood from Mount Wollaston, which he brought— I bespoke also a load of pine-wood from the Railway lots. He asks 2 1/2 dollars a load for cutting and delivering Oak. 1 1/2 dollar for pine, to be brought from the same distance, and 3/4 of a dollar a load for splitting, sawing and piling. I spoke to Farrar about sowing the Oats I bought yesterday of Solomon Thayer. Farrar said he would try them; but that Oats always blasted here. He weighed the Oats but they did not exceed 24 pounds to the bushel— I advised Lieutt. T. B. Adams with regard to his course of reading. My task occupied me till late in the afternoon. I find it necessary to abridge my afternoon’s nap. My brother called, and I rode with him and his Son: to the little Pond, in Braintree; where we saw the new Meeting House that they are building— Returning, I left my brother and his Son at their home— I finished making the copy of W. N. Boylston’s Will; which gives rise to several questions for examination—
24. IV. Friday.

After Breakfast this morning I called at Peter Turner’s Shop, and ordered a pair of Shoes. Lieutenant Adams was here part of the morning— Harvey Field came and talked about butchering, farming, Quincy Canal Shares, and his Rent— He told me there were about twenty-Acres of my Land, under Lease to him, covered with bushes, and yielding nothing but fresh meadow grass, good for nothing which might be brought over to produce English Hay; which he had done with some adjoining land of his own— It is land formerly overflowed by the Mill-Pond; the privilege of which was repurchased some years since— I walked to the ground in the afternoon and viewed it with Mr Field— The Land has gone to Ruin by bad management, and now will cost more to recover than I can expect it will ever yield— Returning home I met a man named Elijah Hayden, who spoke to me about the same land covered with bushes, which he offered to cut down and burn on the ground for me at half a dollar a day. He is now going down to the Bay of Fundy, in a small vessel fitted out from the Point upon the Mackarel fishery. I called at Benjamin Bass’s, and took the Mortgage to George Veazie, who has executed and acknowledged the release— Bass gave me also the Policy, by which he has insured his house at the Office of the Norfolk Mutual Fire Insurance Company at Dedham, which Policy he had transferred to me— I had taken this mortgage, without thinking of the chances of fire, and this incident with many others shews me how ill prepared I am for that vigilant attention to my own affairs which is indispensable for the good management of them. After returning home, at the high tide, I bathed and Swam from wharf to wharf— Charles came out from Boston, and Coll. Quincy and Mr Greene spent an hour of the Evening with us.
25. IV:15. Saturday— Sun rose 4:43.

Commodore Morris and Captain M. C. Perry of the Navy called here yesterday afternoon while I was out— Mr Quincy’s two eldest daughters were here this morning and said he intended to call, but he did not. Lieutenant Adams came in the afternoon and bathed with me at the wharf— I swam from wharf to wharf— The day was so cool and fair that I had no apology for losing time— I worked with the Spade about an hour before dinner, and believe it to be the best of the exercise that I take— I began an abstract of Mr Boylstons Will, thinking to finish it in half an hour, but was occupied with it, all the leisure of the day, and did not half get through— I have an indolent repugnance at commencing upon what I intend shall be the most earnest employment of my future days, and in spite of conviction procrastinate. I had a Conversation with Charles respecting my intention of building which I shall now indefinitely post-pone— I read part of the second Volume of Madame du Deffand’s Letters to Horace Walpole— The relation between them was the most extraordinary that perhaps ever existed between man and woman— Full on her part of affection, and on his of affectation. It is the more remarkable, as among the numerous acquaintance with whom she associated she seems to have had no affection for any one else, male or female. One of her most picturesque Letters in which she gives an account of a personal quarrel between herself and Madame de Forcalquier— She admires Le Vassor’s History of Louis 13. and Walpole who cannot
endure the Greeks and Romans, is quite enchanted with the Abbe Vertot’s history of the Knights of Malta— Nature breaks out in every thing— How could a Son of Sir Robert Walpole be otherwise than disgusted with Greek and Roman History?
26. IV:30. Sunday— 32 years married.

Heard Mr George Whitney; Son of the Minister of the Parish; in the morning from John 9.2. “And his disciples asked him, saying, Master who did sin, this man, or his parents, that he was born blind?” and in the afternoon from Job. 11.7. “Canst thou by searching find out God? canst thou find out the almighty unto perfection?” The first introduced the enquiry into the cause of evil; and the second into the Nature of God— Both these are profound and prolific themes, and it indicates an active and enterprizing mind in so young a man to undertake to grapple with them. They are both beyond the depth of the human fathom; and Mr Whitney’s thoughts are not much matured. The existence of evil, is an objection either against the Power, or against the goodness of the Creator—to which human reason has no answer but ignorance—why it is so, we know not— To pretend to account for it is presumption. An agent, intelligent of cause and effect, is inferable from what we ourselves perceive of the invisible creation— We give the name of reason to the faculty in Man which discerns the relations of cause and effect and we suppose the exercise of the same faculty to be exercised by the Creator. But cause and effect suppose a succession of Time; and to the Creator there is no Time. Cause and Effect suppose change, and in the creator there is no change— Matter exists in space, and space is infinite; but how Spirit can operate upon matter, otherwise than by material agency is incomprehensible— We cannot reason because we cannot know— Mr Quincy, President of the University at Cambridge called on me this afternoon; and agreed to meet me with the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund on Wednesday afternoon at four O’Clock. He had agreed with Mr T. Greenleaf upon Tuesday; but consented to change the day, as I propose going to Weston on Tuesday— I shewed him the drafts of an Account, and of a Deed and mortgage to be executed by the Executors of my father. He approved the account and mortgage; and took the draft of the deed with him for examination. I spoke to him of the donations and bequests of Mr W. N. Boylston, to Harvard University, with regard to which he appeared to be not altogether correctly informed, and I concluded that our future arrangements of that concern should be in writing. He mentioned that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences had this year chosen Mr Bowditch their President— They had for the eight or nine preceding years elected me— And he said Mr Bowditch had desired him to say to me, that he had not accepted, and would not accept without my consent. I requested him to say to Mr Bowditch that I wished him by all means to accept. I have indeed been a mere nominal President of the Academy; never having been able to attend one of their Meetings in that capacity. Mr Quincy said that if Bowditch did not accept there was danger that Professor Farrar would be elected, and Bowditch thought Mr Farrar was now engaged upon other than his proper business. He said also that Mr Bowditch
had been the Salvation of the University— I spent an hour of the Evening at Mr T. Greenleaf’s, where I met Dr Woodward.— T. B. Adams junr. dined with us.
27. IV. Monday.

Mr Baxter who is one of my neighbours came with a plan of a road which he wishes to have laid out from near Mr T. Greenleaf’s corner, over to William Baxter’s.— I went with him over the ground where it is proposed the road shall pass, and it goes through 81 Rods of my land— It is nearly the same with a road which was proposed about 25 years since, and which the Town of Quincy then opposed— I went over it then with a Committee from the Court of Sessions, appointed to examine and Report upon it— Mr Baxter thinks the road would be very advantageous to his Land, and also to mine; which is doubtful. Returning home I stop’d at Mr Brigham’s and took the certificate of the Share N. 25. in the Quincy Canal Stock. Made some enquiries and asked some minutes of Mr Brigham which he promised to furnish me— Mrs Charles Miller and Mrs Smith paid us a morning visit— Dr A. L. Plough a dentist came recommended by himself and by many others to operate upon the teeth. I had one to be drawn, which Mr Parmly some two or three years since had urged me to permit him to do— I had then declined and the tooth had been troublesome to me ever since. I now consented that it should be drawn by Dr Plough, and it took him not more than a third part of 5 minutes— The rest of the time he was cleaning, and filing and dividing my teeth, and in supplying me with tooth powders, and brushes and lotions, enough for a perfumery— Lieutt. T. B. Adams passed the day with us, and Charles came out in the Evening— I read some Letters of Madame du Deffand; but that which I expected would be the most interesting with the Account of the Duke de Choiseul’s dismission is missing.
28. IV. Tuesday.— Weston.

At seven this morning I left home with my Son Charles. At Jamaica Plains in Roxbury, we took up Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and proceeded through Brighton to the farm at Weston, bequeathed to me, by Mr W. N. Boylston— It is leased to a farmer by the name of Amory Conant, who with his brother Silas Conant, lives in the dwelling house, somewhat decayed which is upon the place. They are two young men, both married, and one of them having two or three small children. I inspected the house and out buildings, and took a general view of the land from the immediate vicinity of the house— I authorised them to lay out 20 dollars in new shingling and repairing the house, and suspended the consideration of further repairs upon the house. This farm of near four hundred Acres, was a Bill of Expence to Mr Boylston, and may very easily become one to me— About noon we left the place— Sat down Mr Curtis at his house; and reached home at Quincy to dine at 1/2 past three— The ride was pleasant, and partly over roads where I had never travelled before— The Country Seats upon it are numerous and many of them very elegant. Many of them are built, and the grounds are improved at heavy expence by merchants of Boston who had made great fortunes by Commerce, and spent large portions of them on these retreats— But some have grown weary of their villas, and others have fallen to decay— Many of the places are for sale, and none of them will sell for one fifth part of their cost— Elizabeth H. Foster came out from Boston, to spend a few days with us
Her brother William brought her out, but returned this Evening to Boston. Mr Everett was here this day while we were gone— Mr Barnard, member of the last Congress from Rochester, New-York was with him— He left an invitation for me to dine with him tomorrow, which I shall be obliged to decline— Mr Newcomb came to prevail upon me to have my barn at the foot of Penn’s Hill new shingled; a proposition which I took ad referendum— Visited my garden this afternoon with Charles who found the Peach trees full of worms.
29. III:45. By Candle-light.

I rose before day, and lighted my Candle the first time for the Season. Bathed at the high tide between ten and eleven, and swam from wharf to wharf— I took John Porter with me, and met Price Greenleaf, and my brother’s Sons John and Joseph, as I was returning— I read some of the Laws of Massachusetts, respecting—Executors, Guardians and Trustees and prescribing their duties. Mr. Quincy came at four O’Clock this afternoon according to his appointment; and I attended with him a Meeting of the Supervisors of the Temple and School Fund at Mr T. Greenleaf’s. They passed several Resolutions upon the propositions submitted to them in my Letter; and one for holding an annual Meeting; to appoint an Agent, and to approve the Treasurer’s Bonds— There was much discussion upon the question, whether the Parish will admit the future application of the funds for the support of a Classical School. There are three interests to be conciliated; and three wills to be harmonized— The Town— The Parish, and the Supervisors— There was diversity of opinion as to the mode of proceeding, and not absolutely unanimous zeal for the object itself of the Classical School. The Meeting disclosed to me a part of the obstacles to be surmounted before the School-house can be erected or the School itself established, and raised a very strong doubt in my mind whether it will ever be accomplished, unless by exertions and benefactions by me; and these must be bestowed with the utmost prudence and deliberation, or they will prove abortive— After the Meeting was over Mr Quincy took tea with us, and returned this Evening to Cambridge. Mr Hardwick, wanted to borrow money upon Mortgage, and to sell Saltmarsh Land— Mr Beale brought me a list of the present Proprietors of the Quincy Canal; and repeated a proposition of Mr Brigham that I would purchase the Share notes which constitute the principal debt of the corporation— He wished me also to clear out the brook behind my house, the obstruction to which he says causes the overflow of his meadow. T. B. Adams jr. was here this Evening; Charles went to Boston this Morning, but did not come out this Evening.
30. IV. Thursday—

After completing my Task, with considerable effort, I proceeded upon that of making an Abstract of W. N. Boylston’s Will, which I did not finish— The visitors of the morning were Mr Thaxter and Mr Gay form Hingham— Two persons by the name of Crocker; Cousins, one from the City of New-York and the other from Oswego in that State. Those of the afternoon were Mr Heman Lincoln of Boston, and his brother who were going to Hingham. I read a few of Madame
du Deffand’s Letters— There was a heavy Thunder Shower in the afternoon succeeded by copious rain in the Evening— Mr Holmes was a farming man from Stoughton, who wanted to purchase about twelve Tons of Salt-grass standing, and said he had offered my Tenant Spear two dollars an Acre; which Mr Briesler told him was too much, but which Spear would not take— Charles came out from Boston this Evening.
31. IV. Friday.

Mr Field came to renew his advice to me to undertake the recovery of the Fresh Meadow of the old Mill pond; but was not prepared to give me an estimate of the cost of the work, nor to name a sum for which he would undertake it— He proposed to begin with five or six Acres; and to employ two workmen for three months at my expense for that purpose. I told him that before I embarked I wished to know where I should land. He proposed to hire the farm for five years, at 250 dollars a year the first three years and at 300 the last two, but we came to no definitive determination. Mr Spear came in the afternoon and paid me a Quarter’s Rent for the Mount Wollaston Farm— He had purchased last Spring some grass Seed which proved bad, and wishes to purchase more at my expense; unless his Lease should be renewed. There is also Salt-marsh ditching to be done, and a Cow-yard fence to be repaired— Mr Bailey returned my manuscript reply— James Foster, his wife, and Sister Louisa came on horseback from Dorchester, and after going to my brother’s stopp’d at my door upon their return— Mr Marston and his Son Ward, recently arrived from the Mediterranean were here in the Evening— Charles went into Boston this Morning, and came out at Night.

Day— My time of rising is from 4 to 4:30, but I am usually awake half an hour earlier. I write in my Diary, and dally with the precious moments of the morn till we breakfast between seven and eight. I give one full hour or more to the recovery of arrears in my Diary Index— Write Letters or minutes for the Execution of W. N. Boylston’s Will— Bath and swim at the wharves one hour— Or as an alternative, work with the Spade at my Nursery— Dine at 2. and slumber about two hours after dinner— Receive visitors of curiosity or on business at all hours of the day; and read or write as occasion invites till the dusk of Evening. From that time till the bed, I am unoccupied.
